Posts.Content: May 21, 2010 06:51PM geebung wrote: I am a firm believer in checking any concerning symptom out until you get answers. It's not right that anyone should be made to feel they are overreacting. We know our own bodies and we know when something is not normal. It's much better to overreact than stick your head in the sand. If there is something wrong, then you have done the right thing by catching it as early as possible and if it's nothing, you have peace of mind. I had a spontaneous, blood stained discharge from my right breast for nearly 2 years. I saw several doctors and ended up being referred to a breast centre. Samples of the discharge were sent to pathology. The result - excess estrogen and multiple cysts. All benign. All this time, my left breast was quietly cooking up DCIS and by the time it was found, it was extensive and high grade and I had a mastectomy. So the discharging breast was benign and the other was not. How ironic!

Posts.Content: Oct 12, 2007 03:56PM geebung wrote: Poppy, You are so young - I am so sorry you have to go through this.  I have very opposing feelings about DCIS. On the one hand I am the first to agree that it is the "best" type of bc to have. I had a mastectomy for extensive, grades 2&3 DCIS in April and needed no chemo or rads which was a huge relief. However, losing a breast is sad and a very traumatic experience for many women. Every experience is different and your feelings during your journey will be sometimes unique to you but mostly, shared by your bc sisters.   To begin with, I was in denial, then numb, then panic-stricken, then overjoyed that it was curable. Since then, I have experienced all those emotions alternatively on any given day but now the feelings are more muted.   Think about reconstruction. I haven't had it and I don't think I want to but there are plenty of women who are thrilled with the result. Keep sharing your load with us. hugs, gb

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2008 05:48PM geebung wrote: Hi 31 and welcome. You are at the worst stage of this journey. The unknown, the shock, the fear... you are probably having trouble sleeping, thinking and just doing the day-to-day things. Hang in there. DCIS is virtually 100% curable and microinvasion, although technically taking you from stage 0 to stage 1, is still extremely early and curable. I had a lumpectomy last year for DCIS and the path report also came back saying that there were "several areas suggesting microinvasion". I then had a mastectomy and no microinvasion was found. There will be some of women along soon who did have a small invasion so they will be able to relate their experiences. Listen to Annie - you most certainly will get through this. Please come here whenever you feel the need to vent. There will be lots of sympathetic ears. Hugs, gb

Posts.Content: Aug 4, 2011 09:18PM geebung wrote: Hi brayda, So sorry you are worried and have to wait to see a breast specialist. The younger my children were the more I worried about call backs and anything worrying about my breasts. You are definitely right in getting this checked out. I'm a great believer in any abnormal symptoms being examined by professionals. You are no doubt aware that IBC is rare but, if you log on here, all types of breast cancer will seem to be more common because those of us who have been diagnosed tend to stick around whereas the hundreds (with a few exceptions) who get benign results tend to not come back here. The fewer symptoms you have, the more likely this is not breast cancer. You may have been bitten by some sort of insect and had an allergic reaction, it might be some type of benign skin complaint. However, it's very sensible to have this checked. I hope you can keep very busy over the weekend and up until you see the specialist. I won't tell you not to worry because that's easier said than done but distractions in the form of work and play will help. Above all, please don't read further on these boards about those aleady diagnosed otherwise your imagination will be fuelled to full panic mode. Why torture youself when, in all likelyhood, you are dealing with something totally benign. It's very likely that you will be given the all-clear and will soon be able to put this behind you. Wishing you a distracting weekend, Jane

Posts.Content: Feb 25, 2009 08:41AM geebung wrote: Hi Jodi, I know exactly what you mean about painful mammograms. They have always hurt me - except for the digital mammo I had the year before last. The technician rolled the plate down by hand and the whole process was extremely gentle. I have decided to insist on a yearly digital from now on. Perhaps this was just the skill of the technician - I should imagine she would have been gentle with a regular mammo as well. With regards to your itchy spot, it is sure to be something benign and easily treatable but it's sensible to have it checked out. Last year I had a very annoying itch. It started in my armpit and spread over the right side of my breast, almost to the nipple. My dermatologist said it was a touch of eczema and prescribed some cream. My breast surgeon said it wasn't anything to worry about. Nothing much worked but it eventually went away without treatment. I've never had anything like it before and it did make me think the worst. I have read that inflamatory breast cancer does not disappear and then come back. Once the symptoms are there, they tend to worsen. I am no expert on this and there will be others along soon who know a lot more about this than I do.  Keeping my fingers crossed that you and Sandy will have good news. Jane

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2012 11:27PM geebung wrote: Proudmom, it's a difficult one. You are still concerned yet I know you probably want to avoid surgery if possible. I had a bloodstained discharge from my right breast for about a year. I saw a breast specialist who told me that the discharge was coming from a cyst. She was not keen on my having a ductogram or any surgery and I was happy to take the non-interventionist approach. About 2 years later, when I was diagnosed with DCIS in the other breast, I had a fine needle biopsy of the cyst and the fluid was benign. There will be others who had a different experience who will hopefully tell you of their experiences. This may not be relevant to your situation but over 33 years ago when I was pregnant with my first child, I had bloodstained discharge from both breasts from about halfway through the pregnancy until my milk came in after my baby was born. I think I'm just prone to that sort of thing.

Posts.Content: Jul 17, 2011 01:18PM geebung wrote:  rn4babies, it's an individual decision about your surgery (in consultation with your doctors of course) so my experience is not meant to pressure you into an early surgery. I just wanted to add my personal experience to the others' here in order to help you make your decision. I was dx in early 2007 with DCIS - as soon as the breast specialist looked at my mammogram. She didn't even do a biopsy. Her exact words were: "This needs to come out sooner rather than later. You can wait a few weeks but not months for surgery as this type of cancer can be very nasty if it leaves the ducts". I came home and read up on DCIS and wondered why on earth there was such a rush for surgery.   Anyway, 4 weeks later I had a lumpectomy. The pathology report said it was "over 5.5 cm and extensive, grades 2 & 3 DCIS with microinvasion". My surgeon strongly recommended a mastectomy to which I reluctantly yet readily agreed.  I felt rather pressured about my surgeries but, looking back, I feel that I made the right decision.

Posts.Content: May 27, 2010 12:08AM geebung wrote: Miztress, I'm a great believer in getting checked out if you are concerned about your health. I was just about to wade into the water at the beach when a wave seemed to rise up from nowhere, picked me up and slamed me hard onto the sand. One of my breasts took the full brunt of the impact. Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2008 11:52PM geebung wrote: Randy, I am so sorry you and your wife are going through this. No wonder you are wondering when the other shoe will drop - the whole thing just knocks the stuffing out of you. I think it is not unusual to not have the full picture at the beginning. The really good news is that the nodes are clear but even women with positive nodes have really good odds of long term survival. I initially had a lumpectomy. Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2013 10:08PM geebung wrote: Your skin could well be red because you are touching it so much. It was coming from a cyst and it was completely benign. I hope you can get an appointment with doctor very soon so that this can be resolved quickly. I'm so sorry for your distress.

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2008 06:13AM geebung wrote: Ivy, it's quite normal for you to feel sad. Each person reacts differently and goes through the stages of grief and loss at their own pace. I was constantly told that I was lucky to have dcis and so I was very upbeat for most of the period between my dx and surgeries (lumpectomy followed by single mastectomy with snb). About a month after my second surgery, I began to feel very sad, anxious and alone. I worried that they may have missed something and kept replaying what my surgeon and bc nurse had told me re the strong possibility of invasion and further treatments (ie chemo). I asked for a second opinion on my path slides but even after that I worried for a while. 6 months after my mastectomy I had my first mammogram (digital) and I can honestly say that I wasn't at all worried about what they would find. I was certain it would be ok and it was. So, I guess what i am saying is that it is normal to go through a grief and anxiety stage (even with non-invasive bc) but you do come out the other side and life is good again. Some may need anti depressants (maybe I did? Perhaps I would have bounced back more quickly if I had taken them) and/or counselling. Either or both might be very beneficial to you. Hugs, gb

Posts.Content: Mar 22, 2013 10:01PM geebung wrote: Virginia, Im sending you a cyber hug. I'm so sorry you are going through this... but please, try not to borrow trouble. 80% of breast lumps are benign (actually, I think that figure refers to biopsies and the % of lumps which are discovered...well, I think the odds for those not being cancerous are closer to 90%) and those percentages are across all age groups so the younger you are, the more likely it is to be benign. 41 is still relatively young for breast cancer with most women being over 50 when diagnosed. Having said all that, I know how hard it is not to worry so I suppose I shouldn't tell you that! There are so many other things it could be. There are benign tumors. It could be a cyst - they can be quite large. Fibroadenomas can be large and strangely shaped. How long until you see your doctor? If possible, reassure your children. Tell them that, chances are, it's just a benign lump. Worrying them unnecessarily, at this stage, won't achieve anything. However, please come here and vent as much as you like - that's what this particular board is for. We are here to hold your hand in that horrible waiting period when your mind runs to dark places and you can't sleep or eat. Most of us have been there and we understand. Thinking of you and praying that this all turns out to be boringly benign. Hugs, Jane

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2007 07:37PM - edited Nov 5, 2007 07:40PM by geebung Hi Angie, I only had a unilateral mastectomy (in April this year). I too have a rather uneven scar. It has a small bulge where they did the snb, then it's really flat and right over towards the centre of my chest it's a bit puckered - that's a few adhesions and they block the flow of lymph and it tends to build up there and make things look a bit puffy. I have been having lymphatic massage from a physiotherapist and that really helps. It gets the lymph flowing and, since my wound healed sufficiently, the physio has been working on the scar tissue to help prevent adhesions. Apparently it takes up to 2 years for adhesions to become firmly anchored so if you have pt, they can be gradually broken down and don't stick. There is also kinesio taping which helps to lift the skin and get the lymph flowing. All of these treatments are very gentle and soothing. I asked for a skin saving mastectomy as I thought I might want to have a recon. Therefore, my scar has extra skin around it which makes it a lot less neat. Each to their own but I have decided that recon is not for me. My scar is so much better than it was but I may end up getting a little extra surgery to neaten it up one day - if I can be bothered!  Best wishes, gb

Posts.Content: Mar 20, 2009 07:19PM geebung wrote: I think that anything that grows in the breast can press against other tissue and nerves and cause unusual sensations. I had DCIS and had no symptoms at all - probably because it was confined to the ducts and wasn't pressing against anything, whereas fatty lumps, cysts etc take up space. I hope you can keep busy and distracted until you get a definite result - easier said than done, I know.

Posts.Content: geebung wrote: My history: yearly conventional mammos & ultrasounds all through my 40s. Both breasts have had muliple cysts and were dense. Sudden dx in Feb this year of DCIS. Lumpectomy, dirty margins, mastectomy with snb. Path result: extensive DCIS, grades 2&3, clear nodes, so no further treatment. My aim: to be more proactive with my remaining breast. I have an appointment to have my usual mammo/us in January. I asked my surgeon for a referral to have a digital mammo and he gave me one but he remains unconvinced that digital has any advantages over conventional. Yesterday, when I rang another breast centre to make an appointment to have a digital, I was initially told I would have to wait until at least March. I faxed my referral, they rang back and said they could fit me in this Monday (12th) so I grabbed it!  (Just an aside - I have been nagging my sister all year to have a mammo and FINALLY she has been to see her dr. She told her doc about my dx and as a result she has been referred to have conventional and digital mammos and ultrasound). Sorry to be so long winded about this but here are my questions: do you think I should keep my appointment for conventional mammo & us in January as well as having the digital on Monday? Would this be excess radiation exposure?  Or would it be worth having the 3 different screenings to rule out anything that is hiding? Why is my surgeon so luke-warm about digital when I have read that they are often better at detecting early DCIS than conventional mammo - particularly in dense breasts? I have also read that digital mammo results in more false positives than conventional.  Any thoughts on my ramblings would be very much appreciated. gb  Dx 2/26/2007, DCIS, 6cm+, Stage 0, Grade 3, 0/2 nodes, ER+/PR+ Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 12, 2007 05:48PM geebung wrote: Hope your cold is getting better Di. Zinc & echinacea taken at the first sign of a cold is supposed to lessen the symptoms and decrease the length of the cold. You might reel back in horror when you read my recipe for a hot toddy but you may find it helps! Peel and chop several cloves of fresh garlic (not grown in China!) and add it to about a pint of cold water in a saucepan. Bring to the boil and then remove from heat. Add some freshly grated ginger root, the juice of a couple of lemons, some chilli powder (or use fresh, chopped chillies) and then add some honey to taste. (I try to use medicinal honey which has antibiotic properties) Let the mixture sit for a few minutes (or longer if you want a stronger flavour!), then strain, reheat and drink when needed. You can adjust the ratio of ingredients to suit your individual taste. It might sound yucky but I think it is very soothing and I haven't had a bad cold since I started to use this elixer about 4 years ago.  Do hope you are a lot better soon and that the surgery goes really well. Keep us posted.  gb

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2007 05:09PM - edited Nov 8, 2007 05:09PM by geebung Hi Libby, From what I have read, there seems to be hardly any difference between having a lumpectomy followed by radiation on the one hand and a mastectomy on the other as far as recurrence rates. I have read that high grade DCIS is often more compacted into a small area and is therefore easier to treat with lumpectomy and rads - but this is by no means always the case. Eg, Beesie had high grade extensive DCIS. Mine was also extensive, grades 2 & 3 and after having a lumpectomy, my only choice was a mastectomy.  It is best to be guided by your doctors but, in the end, it is your body and you should choose what you are most comfortable with, whether this be lumpectomy with rads or more aggressive surgery. After the lumpectomy, you will have more information and hopefully, this will make it easier to decide. gb

Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2011 02:58PM geebung wrote: Hi Shonda, So sorry you are worried and yes, the waiting is the worst. I think that a lot of these statements about what bc should feel like are, on the whole, true - ie, perhaps if a survey was taken, a large percenatage of bc patients would not have pain. However, there are plenty of exceptions because each body is different and there are many different types of bc. I'm a firm believer in having all symptoms checked by professionals. I had a spontaneous, blood-stained discharge from my right breast for over a year. I sought  medical advice early, had the discharge sent to pathology and it came back benign. There was no pain. A year or so after that, I turned up for my yearly mammogram & ultrasound and was diagnosed with DCIS - not in the breast with the discharge but in the other breast which had no symptoms whatsoever. The discharge eventually stopped and, apart from frequent cysts in my remaining breast, all is fine 4.5 years later. Chances are, your hard knot and the pain has something to do with the implant but you are most certainly doing the right thing by having it checked. I just wish that you could get an earlier appointment.

Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2012 01:15PM geebung wrote: Hi, So sorry you are going through this. I don't think I've ever had a fibroadenoma so I can't speak from experience. I've had lots of cysts in the past which come and go. I am pretty sure that fibros can grow back after removal but I'm sure there will be posts from people soon who know more about this than I do. Sometimes a lump can be present for quite some time, growing slowly until it gets to a size when you can suddenly feel it and you think it's grown quickly. It's sure to be nothing serious but I'm a great believer in getting all lumps, bumps and symptoms of any sort checked out - for peace of mind or, in the event that it's something more serious, to catch whatever it is early. Breast cancer does occur in people your age but it's very rare so please keep that in mind. However, you need to have this lump checked again by the same doctor and/or another doctor - preferably a breast specialist. You need to have peace of mind.

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2012 07:09PM geebung wrote: Scaredycatwoman, you are a true definition of bravery! To go ahead with a procedure when you are terrified takes a huge amount of guts. I really admire you and I'm so glad the experience wasn't as bad as you thought it would be. I am so sorry this is not the end of testing though, darn it. When I was first diagnosed with DCIS, I went into strong denial - I guess that was my way of coping :-/. Therefore, by the time I turned up for my wire insertion before surgery, the emotions I'd stifled were ready to spill out. I ranted a lot afterwards about the barbarity of such a procedure, but if I had been honest, the whole thing didn't hurt; it was just the thought of what they were doing plus the discomfort of having to sit in a cramped position for so long.The nurse and doctor were unbelievably sweet and kind and I think that partly what made me burst into tear when it was over! Plus the fact that I had bottled up my emotions. My husband wasn't allowed to accompany me so he stayed in the waiting room. It added insult to injury when I discovered him sound asleep in his chair - grrrr!  So, this was what the wire insertion was like for me (5 years ago - things may have changed since then): a) I was seated in front of the mammogram machine and my breast was placed between the paddles b) the area of concern was located c) I was given local anaesthetic and then they waited until my breast was numb (maybe they did this first up?) d) the first wire was inserted - I had to keep very still e) I remember lots of checking and re-checking to make sure the wire was in the right place f) procedure was repeated with 2nd wire g) wires were covered in gauze and taped down h) told my husband off for sleeping! (he's generally very supportive) i) went off to have my lumpectomy. I remember the warm blankets, wonderful pain relief and lovely staff  When I woke up from the anaesthetic, I was asked what my pain level was on a scale of 1-10. I said it was an 8. Within seconds I was given more pain killers and felt no more pain. My scar was about 3 inches long. I wore a firm fitting bra for the next couple of weeks. A seroma formed and I could hear the liquid sloshing around when I walked but it was soon reabsorbed.  Hugs, Jane
Posts.Title: steroetactic biopsy scaredycatwoman geebung

Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2012 10:39PM geebung wrote: Hi again, I'm doing really well, thank you. No tamoxifen for me as my risk of recurrence was/is very low. So glad you have a couple of lovely supportive sisters and glad your husband returned but that must have been horrible for you when he left.  I can understand why you want to get all this over and done with quickly. It's much better to know exactly what you are dealing with than let your imagination take over.  I've heard that MRIs give a lot of false positives so the liver spot is sure to be nothing. I've read of so many women being worried by these liver spots and they turn out to be benign. It's still scary for you though. I didn't have any sedation for my wire insertion. I had to remain very still and listen to instructions as I sat there so I think it would be difficult to cooperate if you were sedated to the degree that you couldn't follow instructions. If I had been given more information about the procedure beforehand, I would have definitely dosed myself up to the eyeballs with Valium though! As I said before, it was certainly not painful but the thought of what they were doing and my fear was what did me in. As you normally take some (Ativan, Xanax?) I think you would need to get some pharmaceutical advice as to how much you should take to cope with this. I'd hate you to overdose but it does sound as though you need to up the dose a bit. I hope you can get advice from you doctor beforehand. The staff where you will be having the wire insertion should be made aware of how you feel, even if you exaggerate a bit to get their attention! I had to sit for about an hour to have the wires inserted. It was a bit uncomfortable to sit for so long - I think the most discomfort was in my back, neck and shoulders. Please let us know what happens.

Posts.Content: Nov 5, 2007 03:13PM geebung wrote: Dear Barbara, Five fur babies! I am envious! Waiting is the pits! I rarely hear of anyone in this bc situation getting everything done quickly. Sometimes anger is a more empowering emotion than fear. There are SO many emotions that we go through and each one is normal. I experienced denial, panic, anger, fear, joy, gratefulness, sadness, confusion...not necessarily in that order. The one thing I think just about everyone will agree with is that we want this thing out of our bodies asap and it never feels soon enough - yesterday wouldn't have been soon enough for me!  Stress and worry can create all types of physical feelings. I was quite a hypochondriac for the first few months after my surgery. I just didn't trust my body any more and wondered what else was in there that I didn't know about.  This next week will probably go irritatingly slowly for you Barbara. It's terrible that you have to wait but, if it's any consolation, we all know how that feels. Try lots of distractions. Ask your dr for meds to help you sleep at night if you have insomnia. I wish I had done that - every night I was up at 2 or 3 am and I couldn't eat much during the day.   I wish that dear little puppy WAS mine! Hopefully, in the new year I will have at least one furry companion again. I love animals with a passion! My dear old cat was put to sleep a couple of months ago and coming home is not the same without a furry one rushing to meet me.  hugs, gb

Posts.Content: Jun 9, 2012 04:30PM geebung wrote: I'm so sorry to know that you are in so much distress over this. You are obviously going through a lot of stress. However, even though you are a medical student, how can you possibly diagnose yourself with stage 11A breastcancer when you haven't even been examined by a professional? The only way you can diagnose breastcancer is with a biopsy. Experienced breast specialists can often be fairly certain that what they see on a mammogram is cancer but even then, they do not give a diagnosis until they have a biopsy that has been sectioned and put under a microscope.  Please don't assume you have breast cancer but get yourself to a doctor and see what he/she thinks. You may need to be referred to a breast centre or breast specialist.   Young women can and do get breast cancer but it is still comparatively rare. Also, 80% of biopsies are negative for breast cancer and that's across all age groups so, for your age, that percentage is probably higher (for not having bc).  Your hard lump is highly likely to be a fibroadenoma - a very common and benign lump in younger women - but, as I am not a dr, I am not diagnosing you as only a pathology lab can do this.  You don't need to tell your family that you have stage 2a breast cancer. You could certainly tell them of your worries and get some support but nobody knows for certain what this lump is until you have it properly checked and this should be done asap so you know what you are dealing with. Best wishes

Posts.Content: Oct 2, 2007 12:22PM geebung wrote: The usual treatment for DCIS is lumpectomy followed by radiation or mastectomy. If the DCIS has become invasive, most women seem to have chemo, even after a mastectomy. Breast tissue can extend up under the arms and of course onto the chest wall. After a mastectomy, the pathologist looks carefully at the margins to make sure that no cancer cells have been left behind. If (and this seems to be fairly rare) the DCIS extended into the chest wall, then radiation would probably be required. If the DCIS had become invasive - ie, had gotten out of the milk ducts, it is no longer stage 0 DCIS, but stage 1 invasive ductal carcinoma in situ and would require chemo. I was diagnosed with DCIs in Feb this year, just after I turned 50. I was initially told that I would most likely have a wide local excision (lumpectomy), followed by approximately 6 weeks of rads, 5 times each week. However, the DCIS turned out to be extensive, stage 0, grades 2&3 so I was advised to have a mastectomy to which I agreed as well as a SNB (sentinel node biopsy - 2 nodes removed which were clear of any cancer cells). After the path report came back, my surgeon told me I was cured and would need no more treatments - no chemo, no rads and no tamoxifen. I have a higher than average risk of developing breast cancer in the other breast but there's an over 80% chance that I will remain (breast) cancer free for the rest of my life. DCIS, although sometimes requiring mastectomy, is the most curable form of bc.  If you have a unilateral mastectomy, you should continue to have regular screening on the remaining breast using mammograms, ultrasounds, MRI etc. Good luck and hugs for your next surgery.

Posts.Content: Aug 8, 2007 12:10PM geebung wrote: Mikim, I read quite a bit about the timing of surgery with regard to menstral cycles and I wanted to have my mastectomy (with SNB) done after my period. However, my medical advisors were urging me to have surgery as soon as possible because they were not sure if my DCIS had become invasive or not. I felt it was necessary to have it done quickly rather than wait until the right time. So I had it on about day 4 of my cycle - I would have preferred to wait a bit longer but there were no vacancies on the surgical list then. Anyway, it all went well. I had minimal pain. Had a drip for the first 36 hours with patient administered pain relief but I didn't need it after the first 15 hours or so. I had one drain from the sentinel node which was removed on day 3. I had my wound manually drained a couple of times after that and have had lymphatic massage regularly during the 3 months since surgery to keep my lymph problems had bay. Overall, it's been ok with a few ups and downs. Hope it all goes as well as possible for you.

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2011 02:19AM geebung wrote: Hi Iznc,  As nobody else has answered your post I will try to jot down a few thoughts. It sounds as though you have very "busy" breasts. It's great that everything has been benign so far but it's annoying and worrying to be subjected to so many call-backs and additional testing. Things could well settle down after a while and you will probably never be diagnosed with breast cancer. However, sometimes, those of us who have had a bc dx had issues with our breasts for some years beforehand. In my case, it was good that I was having regular screening because I was made to be vigilant and, as a result, it was caught at an early stage. I had very dense, fibrocystic breasts and had to have ultrasound as well as mammograms every year. My DCIS was picked up by mammogram. I see that you were diagnosed with bilateral calcifications. Bilateral symptoms are usually benign and many, many women have calcifications - some macro and some micro and they never develop into anything bad. However, in spite of the worry and the nuisance factor of all this breast vigilance, you are doing the right thing.  I'm a great believer in second and even third opinions. These will give you some reassurance. You are managing your health well.  Keep up with your screening and checks. It's a pain I know but it's much better than neglecting your health.

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2009 06:49PM geebung wrote: Hi Stacy, Most of the women who post on these discussion boards have been diagnosed with some form of breast disease. Those women whose mammograms, ultrasounds, other scans and biopsies that result in a benign result tend to not come back here. There are a few who linger on and give their support to women like you who are scared senseless and thinking the worst and this is great - we need them here - but most are out there living their busy lives and do not need our support. So, I hope that what I say from now on will be reassuring to you rather than worrying. I nearly always have call-backs when I have my mammograms. This is because I have cysts that come and go which can look alarming on a mammogram. Luckily for me, I have my yearly mammogram then I sit in a little waiting room in my pink gown while the radiologist looks at the film. It is just great to not have to wait days for the result. Then, I am usually told that I have to have an ultrasound as there is usually at least one suspicious area. Nearly every time the u/s has revealed that the dark lumpy thing on the mammogram is just a fluid filed cyst and I walk out of there very relieved and happy. My diagnosis of DCIS two years ago was unrelated to the cysts. For the time being, this is the best place for you to be. I'd advise you not to go to other threads where people have already been diagnosed because you will be worried even more than you are now. Please try not to think the worst at this stage. The radiology people are probably just being careful and everything will be just fine. I know how hard it is not to worry though. Please post any time as there will always be someone here for you. Big hug, Jane

Posts.Content: Sep 16, 2012 09:16PM geebung wrote: Benny, I would insist on as much anxiety meds as I could get. I've found that if I am relaxed enough, my attitude towards pain changes. Eg at the dentist, I find myself thinking that I don't care if it hurts because I'm feeling so high on the gas. I honestly can't remember if I was numbed before my wire localisation or not...but I do wish I'd had a good dose of valium beforehand - I'm sure it would have made all the difference. NSJ's deep breathing suggestion is a good idea too. After hearing so many horror stories about anaesthesia, I dreaded going under more than I worried about my final pathology. I was sure I'd die from a reaction to it! However, it all went so smoothly. You often tend to get cold when you are stressed so, if you need to, ask for warm blankets to cover you before you go into surgery - it's very soothing to be enveloped in warmth. I remember being wrapped in a pre-warmed toweling robe and it really helped. You will be asked a lot of questions before surgery and weighed so they know what combination of drugs and the quantity to use for your anaesthesia. Praying the whole thing goes smoothly for you. Jane

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2012 01:10AM geebung wrote: Hi Carolyn, Sorry for taking a while to get back to you. I hope you are managing to keep away from Dr Google - there are a lot of scary half truths and untruths out there or just information that doesn't apply to your particular case. Best to come here and just vent and get some support. I had yearly mammograms for most of my 40s because I had "busy breasts" (dense tissue, muliple cysts and a blood-stained discharge for over a year from one side - the good side by the way). Anyway, just over 5 years ago I turned up for my yearly checkup at the breast centre. They told me that day that I would need surgery (must have been a textbook case as I was diagnosed with DCIS just by the appearance of the microcalcifications on the mammogram). I had a lumpectomy which showed the area of DCIS was quite large (over 6 cms), margins weren't clean so I was strongly advised to have a mastectomy with a sentinel node biopsy. I agreed on the spot (I just wanted it all taken away asap).  I was told by the breast specialist that my chance of recurrence is 1-2%. I have not been taking tamoxifen (I doubt I would have agreed to it even if it had been suggested) and I've only had to have yearly checkups since (my yearly mammo and ultrasound will be next week). I was rather anxious for the first 3 years after diagnosis but I really don't worry any more as it all seems a long time ago and I think I was lucky things were not worse. Hoping and praying that there is no DCIS or anything bad for you. Will be thinking of you in Houston and hope to see you back here soon. Hugs, Jane

I was dx in 2007 with DCIS (extensive) and had mastectomy. Personally, I think bc is caused by a combination of things - stress, shift work, environmental toxins (including radiation), personal genetic make up, etc, etc. So, please don't beat yourself up about tucking your cell phone in your bra. There were probably a whole lot of things that caused your problems and you wouldn't have had any control over most of them. Sure it can't help to have a healthy diet, exercise and minimal exposure to radiation etc but I can think of a lot of people who did all the right things and still got it.

Posts.Content: Oct 1, 2007 05:17AM geebung wrote: Hi Jo, so sorry to hear that you are having a painful time. I would say, that as you cut yourself, you should see a doctor. What you are experiencing could be just post-op swelling but best to not take any risks. Swelling under the armpit, around the back and down the side can occur after surgery - particularly after any lymph node removal. If the swelling is due to this, aspiration will give you immediate relief but of course there is a slight risk of infection from having a needle placed in your wound. If the lymph build up continues, you may like to have lymphatic massage - a non-surgical method of freeing up the fluid and helping it to drain into the larger lymphatic vessels. I have found this to be a very gentle, soothing way to bring relief.  Hope you feel much better soon, gb

Posts.Content: Aug 23, 2008 02:28AM geebung wrote: Hi Wiser, As this is your first mammogram, they want to get a really good composite picture of your breasts. This will be your baseline and future pics of your breasts will be compared to these ones. A technician once told me that the mammogram is a macro-view and the ultrasound is micro-view. Also, ultrasounds are useful for checking out any benign cysts which are normally fluid-filled. I started having ultrasounds in at about 40. Right from the start, they did ultrasounds as well as mammograms and nearly every time, they wanted to do extra ones. Ultrasounds are particularly useful for younger women who tend to have denser breasts. Digital mammograms are also better at picking up very early (and completley curable) breast cancers like DCIS. I know, the first time you get a call back, you think the worst but it is highly likely that there is absolutely nothing wrong and they are just being thorough.  Best wishes gb

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2011 04:38PM geebung wrote: Hi Pgf, I had a spontaneous, blood-stained discharge for about a year. I had the fluid examined microscopically and it was benign. I refused a ductogram too because I didn't like the sound of it! My discharge was coming from a cyst. My DCIS diagnosis was in the other breast, which had no symptoms at all. 1. Mammograms have caused leakage from my breast before - although I already had a spontaneous discharge so my experience may not be relevant to your situation 2. If you can afford a MRI, then I think you should have one. The more techniques used to look at the breast, the better the overall picture is 3. I wouldn't wait 6 months as I'm a person who likes to know. An MRI will help you in your decisions. If it shows nothing, you may decide to either have the ductogram or do the wait-and-see approach over the next 6 months. If it does show something of concern, you will have caught it early It's sure to be a benign condition but, as I said before, I think it's best to be sure and have it checked.

Posts.Content: May 14, 2008 08:51PM geebung wrote: Hi Vivian, I had a single mastectomy last year in April not long after I turned 50. In the rapid leadup to the surgery I didn't have any idea how I would feel about reconstruction afterwards so I asked my surgeon to save as much skin as he could in case I did decide to go ahead with it. I had a lot of lymph building up in the months after my surgery and was eventually dx with LE - it's mild but a bit annoying. I have decided not to have reconstruction because I don't want to face more surgery and I have adapted pretty well to my prosthesis. Also, more surgery might worsen my LE. Perhaps one day I might have a simple 'tidy-up' surgery to make my scar neater but I am even shying away from that at the present. I do miss being symmetrical but I generally speaking I am ok with the way I am.  Good luck with your decision. We are all different and I think that, as time goes by, what is right for you will become apparent. gb

Posts.Content: Feb 3, 2009 08:01AM geebung wrote: I don't know about the underarm part (it could be a sebacious cyst or your lymph nodes fighting off an infefection, I don't know) but the oval-shaped things sound like cysts to me. I have had many cysts over the years and they show up on the u/s as dark oval shapes. I had an ultrasound-guided fine needle biopsy on one of them and was surprised at the lack of pain (I had very sensitive breasts) and it was actually quite interesting watching the needle probe about and withdrawing the fluid. They told me shortly afterwards that it was just a fluid-filled cyst - quite benign and harmless. The only reason why they tested this one is because I was about to have a mastectomy on the other side for DCIS & they just wanted to make sure this cyst was clear of malignancy or was not hiding anything else. If they tested all my other cysts, I would be like a pin cushion! Thinking of you and keeping everything crossed that all your results are benign. (Please try not to research these things on the net at this stage as you are sure to find all manner of terrifying possibilites. If you do end up being diagnosed (the odds are you won't be), then is the time to research and arm yourself with knowledge). Jane

Posts.Title: In shock bennymuffins websister

Posts.Content: Sep 15, 2012 12:18AM geebung wrote: We are all individuals with a variety of pain thresholds and emotional makeups so we are all going to react differently to a procedure (hate that word - it's a dishonest euphemism!). I have to admit that my wire localisation didn't actually hurt (I've had far worse pain at the dentist or squeezing a pimple) but my emotional state caused me to see it as barbaric. A rough summary of my thoughts might be something like this: "We as women are expected to endure having wires screwed into into our breasts while we're fully conscious? Imagine a man having something like this forced into his more sensitive areas!" This attitude didn't help me much! I really like farmerlucy's adventurous outlook. It's how I tend to be with medical procedures (did I say I hated that word?!) but I'm afraid I was feeling particularly UNadventurous that day. As I said, it didn't hurt but I didn't appreciated having such a sensitive part of my body impaled with long pieces of wire. (Low blood sugar from fasting and the fact that I was approaching my first general anaesthetic added to my lack of bravery). Out of all those bc related procedures (grrrr!) that I had - lumpectomy, radioactive injections for the SNB and the mastectomy, this was the worst thing - for me. Others will argue that it's a piece of cake. Should I post this? I'm in two minds - my intention is not to worry you but to ask you not to approach this experience certain that it's going to be horrible...from what I've read on these boards, most women sail through it. Most will admit that the worst part is having to sit in an uncomfortable position for so long and having to keep still while the machine (I think it's usually a mammogram) checks to see that the wires are in the right position. I kept very still and stoical until my battered breast was released from the mammogram and then I started shaking and crying. The medical team were very comforting thank goodness...if they'd treated me as though I was a crybaby (which I was!) I would have felt like storming out and finding a cave to hide in. Statistically, you are more likely to sail through this than have my experience but if you do find it not much fun, you will know that you aren't alone...Is that just slightly reassuring? I hope so!  Hugs, Jane

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2009 11:07PM geebung wrote: Hi Amy, sorry to hear that you have these worries. It is scary, isn't it? I'll try not to waffle on but this is my experience with nipple discharge. When I was pregnant for the first time (31 years ago), I read that it was a good idea to gently massage your breasts and try to express some colostrum. So, at about 5 months gestation, I started doing this. There was nothing there but a few days later there were bloodstains on my nightdress. I asked my obstetrician about it and he was unconcerned. He seemed to think it was just early colostrum but advised me not to do any more massage. The discharge continued throughout the pregnancy but disappeared as soon as my milk came in. I successfully breastfed for a long time and gradually weaned my baby during my next pregnancy. I went on to breastfeed my next two children as well. Fast forward to my 40s. I was at the beach. A wave picked me up as I was entering the surf and I was dumped heavily on my breast (can't remember which side now) and a haematoma formed. It gradually seemed to go away but next time I had a mammogram it showed up as a suspicious area and I had a fine needle biopsy. Benign. A few years went by. I started to have a spontaneous bloody discharge from my right breast. Had it all checked out, fine needle biopsy -  benign again - it was just fluid coming from one of my many cysts. It stopped after about a year and I haven't had anything unusual happen with that breast since. My left breast is no more as I was dx with DCIS 2 years ago. Was it related to my accident in the surf? Probably not. Who knows? All is fine now. Somebody on these boards said the other day that, although abnormal, bloody nipple discharge is not usually a sign of cancer.  The tests you have already had are all probably right about your condition being benign but you need to do whatever it is to give you peace of mind. I'm sure there will be others along soon to give you their wisdom. Jane

Posts.Title: Nervous about going for ultrasound Salbi LynneB

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2012 11:59PM - edited Mar 13, 2012 12:00AM by geebung About 20 years ago, I went for a swim at the beach. As I walked into the water, a wave reared up in front of me and dumped me hard on one breast. The pain was so bad that I just crawled out of the water and lay on the sand moaning for quite a while. Some time later, I had a mammogram and there was a dark, shadowy area on my breast. I had a needle biopsy. It turned out to be a large haematoma that had formed when I injured my breast. You may have had a bleed into your breast too and it could be pressing on the breast tissue and causing pain. (Edited to say that most haematomas simply get reabsorbed over time). I'm a great believer in getting anything you're concerned about checked out. If it's nothing, you get peace of mind, if it's something, you can get treatment for it. Sorry you are worried - it's sure to be nothing of great concern but please get it checked out so that you can live your life without this fear.

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2009 09:00PM geebung wrote: Judie, my sister went to Canada last year for the birth of her daughter's first baby. After the arrival of the infant, my niece and her dh thought it was a good idea to go out to dinner, shopping etc as much as possible while granny was there to look after the new bub. My sister would ring me and say how nervous she was (even though she is a mother of 3 herself) - every hiccup, wheeze or grunt made her worry the tiny creature was choking or on the verge of some health crisis! She felt so relieved to hand the baby back to her parents when they walked through the door. Full-time care of an active 2 - 3 year old would be much more exhausting. Perhaps it doesn't matter how laid-back you are as a parent - when it comes to grand-parenting, the responsibility must be much greater, plus lack of practice and being ever so slightly older! I'm sure you are doing a fantastic job but drugs and warm, lavender-scented, candle-lit baths after Connor is asleep at night might be a good idea. This time will pass and you will have good memories. I wish I'd had a mother like you when my kids were young - my mother has always been very un-grandmotherly!

Posts.Content: Apr 26, 2008 12:56AM - edited Apr 26, 2008 01:09AM by geebung Wow Mel! What a sweet kitty Lilly is! I love her pink lips - such femme fatale! She's also a princess with her own palace. She is so lucky to have you as her special human! I love the marmalade bits on her head. She is what we call a tortiseshell - I think they are also known as calico cats? I read somewhere that  such cats are nearly always females. I had one once called Samantha and she was such a sweet cat. Yesterday, the kids from next door came in to give me a letter they had written me - it was so cute! Their little tabby kitten came in with them. I knelt down and patted him and he was so friendly and sweet. The children went home and I came back inside. Next minute Charlie (the kitten's name) was hanging half-way up my screen door, yowling to come in! I went out and told him he should go home and he started purring and rubbing his head against the screen door. I felt like catnapping him!  Karen, I have heard that pugs are such sweet little dogs - very loyal and loving although I haven't known one personally. Most men seem to like biggish dogs - more macho! I like them in any size but I have my heart set on a whippet - preferably a black and white one but I have a feeling they would be quite expensive. I have read up on all the breeds and a whippet sounds like just the sort of dog I want. They are said to be very affectionate,  enjoy exercise but love to curl up on a sofa with you. There's a great website called "whippetwear" and the dogs are wearing the most gorgeous clothes - they are parading on a catwalk (ha ha!) like supermodels. The clothes are pretty expensive though so I would have to try to make something similar as whippets feel the cold.  Settlement is this coming week on the mountains house. My o/h is taking a couple of weeks off soon to help get my house ready for renting. It's an old house (cute but run down) and needs lots of repairs so it's going to take some time to get everything up to a reasonable standard. I am on 2 weeks holiday from my classes. I can't say I am enjoying it all that much. I love the social aspect - my classmates are such a great bunch of people but the subject matter is often very depressing. I live on the edge of an area that has a high rate of unemployment, crime, drug abuse, teen pregnancies and child abuse. It's very sad and every week we have had  guest speakers who trot out the miserable statistics. Usually, it's a case of generation upon generation of unemployment and degradation, too many children, illiteracy and hopelessness. I hope that I can be of some use somewhere...one of these days. My neighbourhood is an unusual mix of wealth and poverty - the haves and the have nots. My neighbours on one side fit the latter category and even though I have supported them as much as I am able, they are still in a very hard place. I feel particularly sorry for their children and their numerous animals - both are neglected and yelled at from dawn to dusk. I hope I don't sound patronising - it could have have been me in such a predicament - divorce, single motherhood, 3 kids...but I had parents who valued knowledge and hard work so I was one of the lucky ones. But even now, there are educated people who work hard but end up losing their homes and have a hard time so it's a tough life for so many people.  I think the most important thing is that people be enabled to help themselves. You can't just give handouts as it just causes dependency and a downward spiral. It's often easier said than done though. Anyway, sorry everyone for raving on. Look at where we are up to - nearly 200 pages of posts! We are a "talkative" lot! I am going to a comedy show tonight and have been up since 5.30am so I am going to try to have a catnap. Hugs to all, Jane

Posts.Content: Oct 20, 2007 03:38AM - edited Oct 20, 2007 03:48AM by geebung Hi Jan, I had a mastectomy with SNB for extensive DCIS 6 months ago and have found that lymphatic massage brings great relief and is very soothing and relaxing. The therapist strokes the lymph from where it is building up to larger drainage channels. Sometimes they apply kinesio tape to encourage the fluid to drain away. I remember the first time I had the tape put on, I went home feeling almost normal again. Six months post surgery I still get a bit of lymph buildup under my arm and also at the other end of my mastectomy wound. Yesterday my lymph therapist taped me again and I feel so much better. I joined up with Curves a couple of weeks ago and find that their circuit training is helping too. Hugs, gb  ps - I have had a prosthesis for a bit over a month and I don't find it very comfortable either. When I walk through my front door, the first thing I do is take it off. It is particularly uncomfortalbe on my mastectomy side. Sometimes I think I should have had a bilat so I would have symmetry.

Posts.Content: Sep 7, 2007 09:00PM geebung wrote: Hi Kittylover, I had a "thingy" grow on my throat very quickly - seemed to almost grow over night. I was convinced it was a skin tag and as it was unsightly and bothering me, I went to my doctor and had it removed. We were both very surprised when pathology came back as a 'squamous cell carcinoma' which is a malignant type skin cancer. Luckily, the margins were clear. I am so glad that I had it removed quickly. Now I have another suspicious looking mole on my back which I am seeing the doc about next week. Anyway, enough waffle about me. I think you should have your spot checked out asap. It's probably nothing but if it is something, getting it early is the way to go. Good luck and keep us posted.  gb

Posts.Content: Jul 2, 2009 05:44PM geebung wrote: Nettie - so good to hear you post. My snb wound was much more painful than my mastectomy. Sue, I think my youngest son had swine flu last weekend. He rang me Saturday night and said he had a temperature and was aching all over. He is a teacher and several kids at his school have it. He felt a lot better on Sunday and was feeling 100% by Wednesday. The media has made a huge fuss about it here and a few people have died but quite a lot of people die from normal flu each year. Most people don't get H1N1 badly - I heard one man being interviewed on tv and he said he'd had "worse paper cuts!" The countries in the southern hemisphere are the main focus of this flu at the moment but, with all the flights around the world, it will continue to spread. Hopefully, by the time the northern hemisphere countries start heading into winter, the vaccine will be widely available. They are starting human trials soon in Australia.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2008 09:43PM - edited Jan 14, 2008 02:10AM by geebung Thank you so much for all the beautiful photos! (And your kind and wise words). Lilly is such a sweet cat - we call that colour tortoiseshell here but I think I prefer the term calico. I think all (or most) cats of this colour are females. So sorry everyone has been having a downer lately. Hot flashes/flushes are the worst. This is why I hate summer! Yesterday it was 35 degrees (Centrigrade!) in my kitchen. I thought I was going to blow up! What with the hot flashes and high temps - very hard to take. Luckily I have a little flat/mini apartment at the back of my house that has air con so my partner and I spent the afternoon out there and just made dashes into the house if we needed something. Today it is cooler and raining and it's a welcome relief. I have to have my first post-dx ultrasound this afternoon and see my bc surgeon. (I had a digital mammo in November and it was clear) so I am not really worried about the u/s but it will be nice to be told that the u/s is clear too. Mel, will be waiting to hear how your sister's test results went. Praying that they will be very benign. So good to see Ulla's post. So sorry your LE is giving you pain. It is just so unfair that you have to have this discomfort along with everything else. Have you seen a LE specialist? Sue, I don't want to sound twee, but you are such a beautiful person. Somebody here said that people who really love you will love you no matter what. Look how much we all love you!! Even before I had bc and mastectomy, I would sometimes see pictures of women with mastectomies and the main feelings I got were huge admiration for them and the idea that this is a different type of beauty. I wish I could do some sort of artistic representation of this new beauty. Photography, sculpture - I am not sure but the women who battle this disease just fill me with respect and love. Wren, I am trained as an elementary school teacher too. I trained late in life and graduated 2 years ago. The first year after that I did relief/casual teaching and the second year (last year) I got bc and had my mastectomy. I found teaching sooo stressful and am hoping to get a job in some other area. My dream is to write and illustrate a children's book but meanwhile I just want to get a job so I can afford to buy paints and other arty stuff as well as pay the bills. My partner gave me some water colour paints and some brushes yesterday so that's a start! Thanks for the lovely story Shirlann - you always have something uplifting to say to us. You are so lovely! Auntie Em - go the bra and panties - that's more than I was wearing yesterday! No, not naked! I just had a sarong wrapped around me. Help! I will miss my appointment! Must rush! Hugs, love gb

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2008 12:16PM geebung wrote: It's 3.30am here and I woke up about an hour ago and can't go back to sleep. Lisa, good luck with all the tests at the hospital - hope everything goes really, really well for you. May you have the best recon possible! I can't remember what type you are having. I wish I had the guts to have reconstruction. Mostly I try not to think about my mutilated body but every now and then I will have a sudden sad thought and tears will come and I wish I could be a have it done. The main thing that is stopping me is that ever since my surgery in April last year I have had lymph build up in my scar and under my arm and I don't want to make it worse with more surgery. It's actually been quite good this week so maybe it's finally starting to abate. I would so hate to get lymphodema. Instead I try to see a type of beauty in my body - something strong which is a symbol of survival and hopefully a stronger me. I don't feel very strong at the moment though - the early morning hours are a bad time to be awake thinking too much! Sorry to hear that Olivia is still sick. I am sure the sight of her dear mother coming in the door will help her to feel a little better.  Sheila, it's hard to imagine such cold weather at the moment as I sit here in my summer nightdress. Although it is almost cool at this time of the morning. It's raining and I can hear the gutters overflowing. Sounds as though you would prefer to have crisp snow than the sleet. I guess you will have to be very careful of black ice. I was surprised to learn that most people don't put chains on their tyres in snowy climates - I don't know how the all-weather tyres manage not to slip and slide on the roads. Although we do hear of multi car pile-ups sometimes. Sue, I am sending you many healing wishes - I so hope that you can really rest and feel better. I'm really really angry with your boss - how can he sleep at night, knowing that he has robbed his hard working staff? The whole situation really stinks. I think we should all storm across to England and demand that he pays you every last cent! My middle son, Heath, sent me a text message yesterday to say that he is loving every minute of his trip to the US. He was in LA and said that everyone is being SO nice to him! When he arrived at LA he bumped into a girl who used to go to his school and she had just had a baby. What a small world! Thinking of you all. I just checked on world times and it's just after 9am Thursday on the west coast and lunch time on the east coast of the US, 6pm in Sweden and in London it's just after 5pm - all on Thursday. So some of you are just starting work, others are having lunch and it's already dark where Ulla and Sue live. It's 4am Friday here - sigh! Well, I am going to have a warm cup of something and try to go back to sleep. love to all gb

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2008 05:52PM geebung wrote: Karen, I had my kids pretty young so I didn't get to finish my education until 2005! I got my degree in teaching then. That first year out of uni I was unable to get a full time job so I did casual teaching and it nearly killed me! The kids have a real attitude to casual/relief teachers who turn up out of the blue if their regular teacher is having a sick day (or can't stand facing her/his class that day -lol). They can make your life hell and you tend to often feel  alienated from the other teachers because you haven't built up relationships with them so you don't get much support. (Although some schools were better than others). It wasn't long before the stress just really got to me and I started making excuses when schools rang to ask me to teach. Then I got bc and that wrote off last year. So now I am going to try again but not as a fully fledged teacher. I want to be a teachers' aide so I can get my confidence up and maybe go back to being a teacher. I am not sure but I just have to try again. I also plan to do a part time course in mental health just in case I discover that teaching really isn't for me. I did find it encouraging that this nice principal I spoke with yesterday told me that he had a similar experience with casual teaching - and that was after he had already been a full time teacher for some years! Have a great weekend, hugs gb

Congratulations beautiful girl on finishing chemo! I know you still feel quite sick but it will get better. Big hugs! Mel - I think your hair looks great! And I think it should be very encouraging for the girls whose hair hasn't grown back yet to see how thick and lustrous it is!  And I haven't seen any fat people in any of the lovely photos so stop it everyone - you are all lovely! Why are we so hard on ourselves? Men get beer bellies and poke them out proudly and pat them! If we put on a few pounds we agonise over it! I haven't been game to post any photos of myself here - partly because I am not sure how to and partly because I hate photos of myself! I would so love to lose 20 pounds. I quite like ginger tea with lemon but if you hate the taste it wouldn't be very nice to have to force yourself to drink it. Also, I am not sure where our fresh ginger is grown but I have a sneaking suspicion that it's from China and there has been so much publicity in the media about pesticides being at very toxic levels in Chinese grown produce.  Sue and Ulla - your sore arms - so sorry you have this to suffer with as well. Have you been diagnosed with lymphedema or is it post surgical edema? Even though edema is painful and annoying doesn't necessarily turn into LE. Mine has flared up the last few days too and is painful and feels bulky. Have been massaging it but nobody can massage like my wonderful p/t and my next appointment isn't for a couple of weeks yet.  The anniversary of my dx is coming up too - Feb 26. I remember thinking I could see a shadow on my right breast this time last year. (I had bleeding from it for about 18 months and my docs were keeping an eye on it. I had a needle biopsy but it was benign. It was my left breast which had cancer all through it - lucky for me it hadn't infiltrated but I was told it almost certainly would have. Cold packs are absolute necessities! I keep them in the freezer/ice box and whip them out as soon as I get a hot flash. I put one on my head, one around my neck and one on my back and suck ice cubes at the same time. At night I just lie there and sweat!  Everyone is asleep now. Hope you all have a restful night. love, jane. xxx

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2008 10:32PM geebung wrote: Hi Mel! My class is interesting but I haven't done my homework! Just bolting down a quick sandwich for lunch and then I will do it. We had a philosophical discussion last class about Mr. Heinz, his terminally ill wife and a phamicist. It is one of those ethical senarios. The pharmacist found a cure for the disease that Mrs. Heinz had and he told Mr Heinz that the vial of medicine would cost $100,000. Mr H didn't have anything like that much money. He loved his wife very much and wanted her to stay with him so one night, he broke into the pharmacist's laboratory and stole the medicine that would cure his wife. Did he do the right thing? We had to break into groups and discuss whether Mr H was right or wrong in his actions. The group I was in was unanimous in saying he was right. It was very interesting to hear the different arguments for and against Mr H's actions in the other groups.  My permission to teach has not come through yet so I am having to put my teachers aid work on hold for a little longer. Posts.Content: Mar 14, 2008 04:22PM geebung wrote: Lisa, I'm glad you are feeling slightly better but I so hope you feel a lot better soon. I made a suggestion in one of my posts that it sounded a bit like a migraine but I think I deleted that part out because I didn't want to sound as though I was diagnosing! I have had occasional migraines over the years - the last one was just before my mastectomy last year. They are helllish! The first time I got one I thought I was dying! I had never had a headache before and suddenly, about 8 years ago they started severe nausea and a headache so bad it felt like an axe had been wedged in my skull. Once I threw up I would start to feel better but always felt exhausted afterwards. I found that strong pain killers that had a tranquiliser added stopped the nausea, dulled the pain and made me sleep it off. I have heard that some people's migraines can last for days - I shudder to think of having to put up with that for that long. I think you should have it checked out - the doc may be able to prescribe something helpful. On a lighter and happier note - that is just wonderful about Olivia's most recent work! She is becoming quite a star. Please pass on my congrats to her - she deserves it - and so do you! You are such a sweet and supportive mother. Posts.Content: Nov 3, 2007 02:55PM - edited Nov 4, 2007 04:05AM by geebung Hi Sue, I am wondering if the dull ache in your neck, chest and wound is caused by a build up of lymph fluid. This is so common after surgery. Sometimes it pools in one place (seroma) and other times it can be over a large area. I still have it a bit in my scar but at its worst it was all over the front of my ribs, round to my back and especially in my arm pit where they removed the nodes. There were no obvious lumps, just a heavy, tender feeling. Lymphatic massage was SO relieving and soothing. Kinesio (sp?) taping brings great relief too as it lifts the skin slightly and the lymph can drain away. I hasten to add that if this is what is causing the ache, it doesn't mean you have lymphoedema but post surgical edema. It will eventually settle down but it can be uncomfortable. Perhaps you are working too hard - if you use the surgical side too much it can cause an increase in lymph.  It's so interesting about the vinegar cravings and extreme fatigue and great that you don't have them any more. You are doing so well Sue. I will be thinking of you especially over the next few days before the onc appointment. Great idea to jot down your questions - it's so hard to think of them when you are sitting in front of the dr. Well, I'm off to see Miriam Margolyes, a British actress (she was in at least one of the Harry Potter movies). She's doing a show called "Dickens' (Charles) Women". I saw her interviewed on tv and she is hilarious.  Enjoy your day off Sue. Hope you can do something indulgent and relaxing. Lots of love, gb

Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2008 06:25PM - edited Jun 4, 2008 06:28PM by geebung Karen, this is such a hard time for you and your parents. I am so sorry that you have to face such sadness and worry when you are still fragile from your own recent treatments and all the stress, exhaustion and worry that has caused. Please don't ever feel that you are a broken record. This is sad, unfair and just plain horrible for you all and you need as much support and love as possible at this time. Love to you sweet one. Ulla - I am no authority on tamoxifen but everyone is different as to how they react to medications. I find it very frustrating when people say that your  body "should" or "shouldn't" be reacting in a certain way...you are you and your metabolism is different to other women. From what I have heard and read, there are lots of different reactions to tamoxifen at the beginning of taking the medication and these usually settle down. I'm sorry this is upsetting you and giving you worry. Hope it is all sorted out soon. Ann, I hope you feel better soon. You probably need to cry some more and let it all out. I bet you have been bottling up your real feelings for such a long time and they need to be released. The Zoloft has been blocking things and has been useful in getting you through but perhaps it is good for you to have gone off it for a short time to let your emotions vent? Nancy - I love to hear of divorced couples who can forget their differences and forge a new friendship. If only people could do this for their kids, I'm sure divorce would lose a lot of its sting. Posts.Content: Jan 26, 2008 03:17PM geebung wrote: Hi Cyndy, So sorry you are going through this trauma and anguish. It is scary and overwhelming to be told that you need a mastectomy and you need some time to come to terms with this. At this stage, it seems to me that you have non-invasive bc and that is the "best" type to have. I had ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) all through my left breast. I had a lumpectomy first but no clear margins so I had a mastectomy last April. There is usually no rush for surgery for DCIS because it hasn't invaded. However, until the final pathology comes back they can't rule out invasion. My surgeon was in a hurry to operate because the first path report suggested invasion. However, the path on my mastectomy showed no invasion so I didn't have to have chemo or rads. The big question that nobody can answer is which DCIS will spread? If only we knew! I was very eager to have my mastectomy because I didn't want to take any chances - I was told that, due to the aggressive character of my bc, that it could infiltrate at any time so I am grateful that they found it when they did. Now, about double mastectomies. One of my friends had this done and she is coping well. She also had quite big breasts but has decided against recon. She chooses to wear a double prosthesis.  It's a really individual thing. You could have a single mastectomy with a reduction on the other breast if you wanted to and then wear a prosthesis on the mastectomy side. Or you could have a bilateral mastectomy done and have a recon the size that you would like. There are quite a few options. For now though, you need lots of support and understanding ears. Don't feel rushed unless there is good reason to have surgery sooner rather that later. If you have worked in oncology, you no doubt know a lot more than I do so what I have said is probably not new to you. The most important thing for you now is to vent, yell and find support. You are very welcome here. Hugs, gb (Jane)

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2010 06:06AM geebung wrote: In a nutshell, any surgery to the breast area can cause LE, radiation can also contribute and so will the revoval of nodes under the arm, although there is definitely less risk with a SNB than with multiple removal. Most doctors will say that LE after a SNB is extremely unlikely but, my own experience shows that it is possible. Before my mastectomy and snb, the breast centre referred me to their resident physiotherapist who explained about lymphoedema, gave me exercises to do after surgery and said she would be seeing me 2 weeks after surgery to see how I was healing. After surgery (2 sentinel nodes removed), I had to have my wound drained several times after having my drains removed (they were removed on the 3rd day). I kept my appointment with the physio who gave me a gentle lymphatic massage. I saw her a couple of times after that for massages. After about 8 weeks, I was still feeling swollen and uncomfortable. At my bc support group, another physiotherapist was recommended so I went to her for ongoing therapy. She diagnosed me with mild lymphoedema (truncal and in my arm) and treated me with lymphatic drainage massage and kenesio taping. She also taught me how to do self massage and fitted me with a full sleeve.  I continued recieving LE treatment for nearly a year after surgery and the LE gradually diminished. I no longer wear my sleeve and life has returned pretty much to normal. I think that early intervention and the therapy I received were invaluable to me. I leaned a lot about the condition and I feel sure that the therapy prevented the LE from becoming more severe. I don't wear an LE alert bracelet but I think it's a great idea.  So, if you can find a good LE therapist, I would recommend making an appointment, getting base line measurements of your arm and learning as much as you can about the condition and prevention.

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2008 04:01PM - edited Feb 2, 2008 04:02PM by geebung Lisa, hope you have a great night out. Will be sending you lots of positive thoughts for Monday. How wonderful that your niece will be with you during your surgery! That is very special. It's so great that your dd could be with you for a couple of days but sad that she has broken up with her b/f. I hope she enjoys her outing with your friend's handsome son! No harm in a bit of match making - I think friends and family can often see possibilities and these often work out. Sue, your busy and stressful day sounds exhausting. I am sure you are a very good boss and it sounds as though you have some very difficult situations to deal with. You had every right to yell! People who slacken off when there is so much to be done all around them make more work for everyone else. Probably a good thing to leave the Adam thing until Monday - surely he's expecting it! You can't choose the pub over work if want to keep your job! Ulla - interesting article but not sure if I agree with it! No doubt there are many things in our environment that cause bootface - it's probably not one but many factors and it's very difficult to avoid all these toxins. I don't like it when they talk about personality types getting cancer or attitudes because it puts the blame right back on the patient. Of course we all have a responsibility to live as healthfully as possible but I know several people (myself included) who have had good diets, exercised and had positive attitudes  and yet we still got it! I constantly see articles on studies that suggest that certain lifestyles, foods, etc cause bootface and they do probably all contribute...one of the latest causes was shiftwork - well, I worked nightshift for 2 years but a lot of other people I worked with are still fine so...who knows? Here's a link that I found: http://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20080129/hl_nm/cancer_breast_personality_dc_2 Jane xx

My sister is back in Burlington now, staying with her daughter, waiting for the baby to be born. She was due on the 18th Feb so she's now almost 2 weeks overdue! The baby is small and they are keeping a careful eye her and my niece. Lucy - atagirl! Wow - it all sounds so intense and romantic - just what you needed! I think we need to see some pics soon! Well, I had a very busy week. Eldest son came back from Cambodia, I started my mental health course (great bunch of people - really diverse, fun and friendly) and yesterday my dh and I went up to the mountains again to look at more houses. My favourite is still the first one we looked at but we did see 2 more that are worth considering. It was delightfully cool up there and we had to rug up - we both love the crisp, clear mountain air and the beautiful gardens and trees. I would love to live there.  I think my LE is improving - the swelling seems to be decreasing. I was a bit upset when my wrist got all lumpy about 10 days ago but I think that wearing my compression sleeve 24/7 and massaging it am & pm has helped a lot. I loved all your funny sentences from that game - my vague brain can't remember who started it - was it you, Sheila? The sniffing one was funny! Love to you all - including Mel, Tender, Dawn, Angie, Karen, Melody, Ulla, Vasul, Karyll, Wren and the new girls who posted here - can't remember your names but if I scroll back to look I might lose my post - great to see your comments.  Time for bed! Posts.Content: Mar 4, 2010 12:36PM geebung wrote: Hi everyone, I woke up at 3.30 am and decided to get on the computer. I hate the way I wake up so early and start to worry about things that don't bother me as much during the day. Cathi, I think about you each day. I'm so glad to hear that the new pain med is working well for you. I hope you get some warm weather soon. Also, hoping that the appointment for Landon goes well and that he is not too scared. Poor little guy. I had those absence seizures when I was a kid. My brother used to pick me up while I was having one and run with me to another room or area. When it was over (only a matter of seconds or minutes I think) I would be very confused as to how I got to where I was because I had no awareness during the seizure. My mother thought I was just a bit dreamy and it wasn't until a friend with medical training suggested that she take me to a specialist that she made an appointment for me. I had an ECG and was dx. I grew out of it by the time puberty started. Sheila, I hope your experience and dedication in your job brings you something better. Also, I'm sorry to hear about your concerns re your cervix. I do know several people who have had abnormal pap tests and most were just inflammation.  I hope you get your path report soon and you will know just what you are dealing with. Posts.Content: May 9, 2009 06:24AM geebung wrote: Most younger women have dense breasts so an ultrasound is a good adjuct to mammography. U/s is better at picking up cysts. MRIs often pick up things that mammos & U/S don't. On the other hand, I have read that they do give a higher percentage of false positives. A combination of screening methods is good because each one has strengths that the others lack and so a clearer overall 'picture' is obtained. If you are still concerned, a biopsy followed my microscopic assessment of the tissue sample is the most reliable diagnostic method of all. Go with your gut feeling and pursue this until you are satisfied. I hope and pray that the result will be convincingly benign.  Jane

Posts.Content: Oct 23, 2007 03:03PM - edited Oct 23, 2007 03:04PM by geebung Dear sweet Sue, I'm so glad your SO is going with you tomorrow. It is sad to lose your breast - I too imagined mine, sitting alone in a lab jar somewhere...but it was no longer my friend. Of course you are feeling sad - who wouldn't? You have had weeks of stress and anguish, pain and worry. You have done so well, keeping your sense of humour and reaching out to others - you are a very precious member of this community. So many women have "snowstorm" breasts, flecked with calcifications, cysts and various tissues that show up as shadows and white things. Please don't think that every white dot and flash that you saw is sinister. I just read that 70% of bc begins in the ducts, 10% in the lobules and the remainder in other breast tissue. A general asaesthetic takes a while to recover from. The flashy pains are most probably caused by stress and lack of sleep.  We are all holding you very close - imagine a huge group hug that goes all around the world - all of your sisters with interlinking arms - we love and care for you. love, gb
